quest_title: If a train travelling at 72 kmph is to be brought to rest in a distance of 200 metres, then its retardation should be
explanation_txt: \(\begin{array} { l } { u = 72 \mathrm { kmph } = 20 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s } , \quad v = 0 } \\ { \text { By using } v ^ { 2 } = u ^ { 2 } - 2 a s \Rightarrow a = \cfrac { u ^ { 2 } } { 2 s } = \cfrac { ( 20 ) ^ { 2 } } { 2 \times 200 } = 1 \mathrm { m } / \mathrm { s } ^ { 2 } } \end{array}\)

quest_title: Which of the following is true for elastic potential energy density?
explanation_txt:
Energy stored \((U)=\int Fdx=\int_{0}^{l}kxdx=\cfrac{1}{2}kl^{2}=\cfrac{1}{2}(kl)l=\cfrac{1}{2}\times P\times l=\cfrac{1}{2}\times \cfrac{P}{A}\times (AL)\times \cfrac{l}{L}=\cfrac{1}{2}\sigma \times V \times \varepsilon\)

\(\Rightarrow \cfrac{U}{V}=\cfrac{1}{2}\times \sigma \times \varepsilon\)

\(\therefore\) Energy Density \(= \cfrac{1}{2} \times\) Stress \(\times\) Strain
question_plain_title: Which of the following is true for elastic potential energy density?
explanation_plain_text:
Energy stored

Energy Density Stress Strain
ans1_plain_text: Energy density strain stress
ans2_plain_text: Energy density strain volume
ans3_plain_text: Energy density strain volume
ans4_plain_text: Energy density stress volume

quest_title: A machine having efficiency 75% uses 12 J of energy in lifting up a 1 kg mass through a certain distance. The mass is then allowed to fall. The velocity of ball at the end of fall is
explanation_txt:
75\(\%\) of \(12=m g h\)
or, \(h=\cfrac{0.75 \times 12}{1 \times 10}=0.9 \mathrm{m}\)

Again, \(v^{2}=0^{2}+2 g h\)
or, \(v=\sqrt{2 \times 10 \times 0.9}=\sqrt{18} \, \mathrm{m} / \mathrm{s}\)

quest_title: The magnitude of saturation photoelectric current depends upon
explanation_txt:
The value of saturation current depends on the number of electrons ejected. Number of electrons ejected depends upon number of photons incident i.e. intensity of light.

It is independent of stopping potential, frequency and work function.

quest_title: A charge q is placed at the centre of line joining two charges Q. The system will be in equilibrium if \(\text{q}\) is equal to
explanation_txt:
For the system to be in equilibrium, net force on \(Q\) should be zero
i.e. \(F_{1}+F_{2}=0\)
Or, \(\cfrac{1}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}} \cfrac{q Q}{x^{2}}+\cfrac{Q Q}{4 \pi \varepsilon_{0}(2 x)^{2}}=0\)
Or, \(\cfrac{Q q}{x^{2}}=\cfrac{-Q Q}{4 x^{2}} \\ \therefore q=\cfrac{-Q}{4}\)

quest_title: Each of resistance in network shown in figure is equal to \(\text{R}\). The resistance between the terminals \(\text{A}\) and \(\text{B}\) is
explanation_txt:
The circuit can be redrawn as Wheatstone’s bridge. The bridge is balanced circuit.

\(\cfrac{1}{R^{\prime}}=\cfrac{1}{2 R}+\cfrac{1}{2 R}\)
\(\cfrac{1}{R^{\prime}}=2 \times \cfrac{1}{2 R}\)
\(\therefore R^{\prime}=R\)

quest_title: The equation of the line bisecting the line segment joining the points (a, b) and (a', b') at right angle, is
ans1_txt: \( 2 \left( a - a ^ { 2 } \right) x + 2 \left( b - b ^ { \prime } \right) y = a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } - a ^ { \prime 2 } - b ^ { \prime 2 } \)
ans2_txt: \( \left( a - a ^ { \prime } \right) x + ( b - b ) y = a ^ { 2 } + b ^ { 2 } - a ^ { \prime 2 } - b ^ { \prime 2 } \)
explanation_txt: \( \begin{array} { l } { m = \cfrac { - 1 } { \cfrac { b ^ { \prime } - b } { a ^ { \prime } - a } } = \cfrac { a ^ { \prime } - a } { b - b ^ { \prime } } . \text { Mid point is } \left( \cfrac { a + a ^ { \prime } } { 2 } , \cfrac { b + b ^ { \prime } } { 2 } \right) } \\ { \text { Therefore equation of line is } y - \left( \cfrac { b + b ^ { \prime } } { 2 } \right) = \cfrac { d - a } { b - b ^ { \prime } } \left( x - \cfrac { a + d } { 2 } \right) } \\ { \Rightarrow 2 \left( b - b ^ { \prime } \right) y + 2 \left( a - a ^ { \prime } \right) x - b ^ { 2 } + b ^ { \prime 2 } - a ^ { 2 } + a ^ { \prime 2 } = 0 } \end{array} \)

quest_title: If for a plane, the intercepts on the coordinate axes are 8, 4, 4 then the length of the perpendicular from the origin on to the plane is :
explanation_txt:
Equation of plane is,

\(\cfrac{x}{8} +\cfrac{y}{4} +\cfrac{z}{4} =1\)

\(\Rightarrow\)\(x+2y+2z=8\)

Length of the perpendicular from the origin on the plane \(=\left|\cfrac{-8}{\sqrt{1^{2} +2^{2} +2^{2} } } \right|=\cfrac{8}{3} \).

A block of mass 1 kg is placed on the horizontal surface of a truck moving with an acceleration of 5 m/s\({}^{2}\) . If coefficient of friction between the surface of truck and block is 0.6, the frictional force on the block is
explanation_txt:
Limiting force of friction,

\(F_{f}=\mu_{s} R=\mu_{s} m g=0.6 \times 1 \times 10=6 \mathrm{N}\)

Resultant force (FR) = ma = 5 N

∴ Frictional force (F) = 5 N
question_plain_title: A block of mass 1 kg is placed on the horizontal surface of a truck moving with an acceleration of 5 m/s . If coefficient of friction between the surface of truck and block is 0.6, the frictional force on the block is
explanation_plain_text:
Limiting force of friction,

Resultant force (FR) = ma = 5 N

∴ Frictional force (F) = 5 N

quest_title: Two water pipes of diameters 2 cm and 4 cm are connected with the main supply line. The velocity of flow of water in the pipe of 2 cm diameter is
ans1_txt: 4 times that in the other pipe
ans2_txt: 1/4 times that in the other pipe
ans3_txt: 2 times that in the other pipe
ans4_txt: 1/2 times that in the other pipe
explanation_txt:
\(d _ { A } = 2 \mathrm { cm } \text { and } d _ { B } = 4 \mathrm { cm } \therefore r _ { A } = 1 \mathrm { cm } \text { and } r _ { B } = 2 \mathrm { cm }\)

From equation of continuity, av = constant

\(\therefore \cfrac { v _ { A } } { v _ { B } } = \cfrac { a _ { B } } { a _ { A } } = \cfrac { \pi \left( r _ { B } \right) ^ { 2 } } { \pi \left( r _ { A } \right) ^ { 2 } } = \left( \cfrac { 2 } { 1 } \right) ^ { 2 } \Rightarrow v _ { A } = 4 v _ { B }\)
question_plain_title: Two water pipes of diameters 2 cm and 4 cm are connected with the main supply line. The velocity of flow of water in the pipe of 2 cm diameter is
explanation_plain_text: From equation of continuity, av = constant
ans1_plain_text: 4 times that in the other pipe
ans2_plain_text: 1/4 times that in the other pipe
ans3_plain_text: 2 times that in the other pipe
ans4_plain_text: 1/2 times that in the other pipe

explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)m = \( \cfrac{I}{O} = \cfrac{3}{1} \) = 3

\(\quad\)m = \( \cfrac{v}{u} \)

\(\quad\)\(\therefore \) v - u = 1m

\(\quad\)u = 1m

\(\quad\)\(v\) = 3m

quest_title: If two tuning forks 'A' and 'B' are sounded together they produce 4 beats/sec. 'A' is then slightly filed, they produce 2 beats/sec when sounded again. The frequency of 'A' is 265. The frequency of 'B' will be
explanation_txt:
Hence frequency of fork \(\mathrm{B}=252 \mathrm{Hz}\)
\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{A}}=256 \mathrm{Hz} ; \mathrm{m}=4\)
\(\mathrm{f}_{\mathrm{B}}=252 \mathrm{Hz}\) or 260 \(\mathrm{Hz}\)
Due to filing frequency of tuning fork 'A' increases and no. of beats decreases with frequency 260 \(\mathrm{Hz}\) . Hence frequency of tuning fork \(\mathrm{B}=260 \mathrm{Hz}\)

quest_title: If the \(m^{th} \) term of a H.P. be \(n\) and \(n^{th} \) be \(m\), then the \(r^{th} \) term will be
explanation_txt:
Given \(T_{m} =n,\; T_{n} =m\) for H.P.

Therefore for the corresponding A.P. \(m^{th} \) term \(=\cfrac{1}{n} ,\; n^{th} \) term \(=\cfrac{1}{m} \)

Let \(a\) and d be the first term and common difference of this A.P., then;

\(a+(m-1)d=\cfrac{1}{n} \quad (i) \)

\(a+(n-1)d=\cfrac{1}{m} \quad (ii) \)

Solving these, we get \(a=\cfrac{1}{mn} ,\; d=\cfrac{1}{mn} \)

Now, \(r^{th} \)term of corresponding A.P

\(=a+(r-1)d=\cfrac{1}{mn} +(r-1)\cfrac{1}{mn} =\cfrac{1+r-1}{mn} =\cfrac{r}{mn} \)

Therefore \(r^{th} \) term of corresponding H.P. is \(\cfrac{mn}{r} \).

explanation_plain_text:
Given for H.P.

Now, term of corresponding A.P

quest_title: A person can't see nearer than 50cm. The lens required to read a book at 25cm is
explanation_txt:
\(\mathrm{v}=-50 \mathrm{cm} \quad \mathrm{u}=25 \mathrm{cm}\)
\(\mathrm{f}=\cfrac{\mathrm{uv}}{\mathrm{u}+\mathrm{v}}=\cfrac{25(-50)}{25-50}=50 \mathrm{cm}=0.5 \mathrm{m}\)
\(\mathrm{P}=\cfrac{1}{\mathrm{f}}=\cfrac{1}{0.5}=+2 \mathrm{D}\)

quest_title: a child is looking into a small polished hemispherical bowl sees erect image is himself at 21cm from bowl. He turns the bowl then image is seen at 7cm from bowl. The radius of curvature of bowl will be
explanation_txt:
\(\quad\)\(1^{st}\) case

\(\quad\)u = \( \cfrac{fv}{v - f} = \cfrac{f\left(-21\right)}{-21 - f} \)

\(\quad\)\(2^{nd}\) case

\(\quad\)u = \( \cfrac{fv}{v - f} = \cfrac{\left(-f\right) \left(-7\right)}{-7 + f} = \cfrac{7f}{f - 7} \)

\(\quad\)Now, \( \cfrac{f\left(-21\right)}{-21 - f} = \cfrac{7f}{f - 7} \)

\(\quad\)or, -3f + 21 = -21 - f

\(\quad\)or, 2f = 42

\(\quad\)f = 21cm

\(\quad\)R = 2f = 42cm
question_plain_title: a child is looking into a small polished hemispherical bowl sees erect image is himself at 21cm from bowl. He turns the bowl then image is seen at 7cm from bowl. The radius of curvature of bowl will be
explanation_plain_text:
case

u =

f = 21cm

R = 2f = 42cm

quest_title: On increasing the temperature of a conductor, its resistance increases because
explanation_txt: Resistance of conductor depends upon relation as \(R \propto \cfrac { 1 } { T}\). With rise in temperature, molecular vibrations increase. This reduces mean free path of electrons so relaxation time decrease and hence resistance increases.

quest_title: Let \(f ( x ) = \left| \begin{array} { c c c } { x ^ { 3 } } & { \sin x } & { \cos x } \\ { 6 } & { - 1 } & { 0 } \\ { p } & { p ^ { 2 } } & { p ^ { 3 } } \end{array} \right|\) where p is a constant. Then \(\cfrac { d ^ { 3 } } { d x ^ { 3 } } \{ f ( x ) \} \text { at } x = 0\)
explanation_txt:
\(f ^ { \prime \prime } ( x ) = \left| \begin{array} { c c c } { \cfrac { d ^ { 3 } } { d x ^ { 3 } } x ^ { 3 } } & { \cfrac { d ^ { 3 } } { d x ^ { 3 } } \sin x } & { \cfrac { d ^ { 3 } } { d x ^ { 3 } } \cos x | } \\ { p } & { - 1 } & { 0 } \\ { p } & { p ^ { 2 } } & { p ^ { 3 } } \end{array} \right| = \left| \begin{array} { c c c } { 6 } & { - \cos x } & { \sin x } \\ { 6 } & { - 1 } & { 0 } \\ { p } & { p ^ { 2 } } & { p ^ { 3 } } \end{array} \right|\)

\(\therefore f ^ { \prime \prime \prime } ( 0 ) = \left| \begin{array} { c c c } { 6 } & { - 1 } & { 0 } \\ { 6 } & { - 1 } & { 0 } \\ { p } & { p ^ { 2 } } & { p ^ { 3 } } \end{array} \right| = 0 , \text { which is independent of } p\)

explanation_txt:
For \(\vec{F_{1}}\times \vec{F_{2}}=0\),

\(\vec{F_{1}}\) and \(\vec{F_{2}}\) should be parallel.

Since \(\vec{F_{1}}=k_{1}\hat{i}\), \(\vec{F_{2}}\) should also be \(k_{2}\hat{i}\).

\(\therefore \vec{F_{2}}= - 4 \hat { i }\)
